newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Massive S.Korea manhunt after submarine landing.
newsitem.headline: Massive S.Korea manhunt after submarine landing.

text.p: South Korean troops on Wednesday staged a massive night-time manhunt for an estimated eight or nine North Koreans still at large after a submarine went aground and 11 suspected infiltrators were found shot dead.
The search followed a day in which South Korea had to face up to what was apparently the most serious infiltration from the communist North since the 1960s.
Seoul angrily denounced it as a breach of the 1953 Korean War armistice agreement which sealed the partition of the peninsula. There was no immediate reaction from the Northern capital, Pyongyang.
Authorities believe around 20 North Koreans were landed by submarine on a beach south of the border between the two hostile states.
A taxi driver spotted the submarine soon after midnight on Tuesday, stranded on rocks nine kilometres (5.6 miles) south of the east coast city of Kangnung.
Authorities said it had apparently hit a reef while attempting to return to the North after dropping off the infiltrators.
Later the bloodsoaked bodies of 11 of the North Koreans were found on top of a mountain, dressed in jeans and sneakers.
"One of the dead infiltrators had a gun on him and we think he killed himself after shooting the others," a Defence Ministry spokesman told a news conference.
A 12th man was captured alive after authorities launched the huge manhunt, and his initial testimony apparently contradicted the official version of a planned mass infiltration.
Television news reports said Lee Kang-soo, 31, told interrogators the submarine had drifted into South Korean waters after developing engine trouble.
There was speculation that the submarine could have been sent to pick up an agent or drop off a small unit of spies -- and that the mission then went badly wrong.
Television pictures showed the abandoned vessel bobbing helplessly in the water. Troops who boarded the grey craft found automatic guns and ammunition, along with canned food and shoes.

Thousands of troops and police using sniffer dogs combed terrain around the beach as helicopters roared overhead. They set up checkpoints on all main roads. Naval vessels and a reconnaissance plane joined the search.
After authorities imposed a dusk-to-dawn curfew in the area, two North Koreans burst into a village home and stole food and cigarettes from the owner at gunpoint, state radio reported.
Later, security forces exchanged gunfire with two infiltrators near an airport serving Kangnung, television news said. The skirmish lasted for about 15 minutes but the two managed to evade capture.
"This incident is a grave provocation and a definite infiltration against South Korea by North Korea," Kim Dong-shin, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told a news conference.

Unification Minister Kwon O-kie chaired a meeting of cabinet ministers who deal with security-related matters which declared the infiltration "a direct threat to our national security", a Unification Ministry statement said.

Yonhap news agency quoted a former North Korean commando, captured while on a mission to kill South Korea's president in 1968, as saying the submarine could have been planning to bring home a Pyongyang agent.
"The submarine may have hit rocks by mistake and then all members of the crew fled onto land after finding it impossible to go back," Kim Shin-jo was quoted as saying.
Adding weight to this speculation were signs of panic flight, with personal belongings scattered along a road.

Wednesday's drama was one of the most deadly since 1968 when 31 North Koreans reached the presidential Blue House in Seoul. Twenty-eight were killed in a gunbattle in which 34 Southern troops, police and civilians also died.

Shin Sang-kil, deputy head of operations of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told reporters troops had found a machinegun with 75 rounds of ammunition, a Soviet-made rifle with 100 bullets and 75 other bullets on the vessel.

The Defence Ministry said the Sang-o class submarine measured 34 metres (111 ft) in length and weighed 330 tonnes. North Korea has about 10 of these submarines, each capable of carrying 21 people, a ministry official said.
